column4: Is there a way to uninstall grub from the master boot record? :)
- there probably is a bettr way to do this but, i use the "dd" command dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/YOUR_DRIVE   (please google this for settings to match what you want to do.)

And recently a fat32 partition on the disk that /root is on went to hell....  If it was a software issue, all is good.. Ifit was hardware, then I need to get that drive outa the boot loop before it dies for real.
If I could get a copy of WinXP Home SP 2, for like 6 minutes, I could have it all fixed. :P But all anyone has are those damned recovery disks. Hehehehehe
lol - after 3 weeks i know just enough to be dangerous
you should see what a newb like me can do with file permissions. - lol
Thanks to grub, if that happens, my system will be a paperweight with anything shortof a low level format and reinstall of everything.
Because, if I can rewerite it to where it only looks at windows, it will not require the second drive to boot propperly.
because grub wrote to the master boot record, to look at data on the second physical drive.
- If you get into trouble (and i have already) try Helix Linux to rescue any files.
:P  See... I got myself in a jam becauseo f windows. :P hehehe
Last time I ran into an issue where it couldn't read the config files, I had to use the rescue disk. ^_^
I think the version of grub I have is a little retarded!  ^^;; I like lilo better anyway *pouts*
Lilo writes EVERYTHING to the boot record. :P so if one drive dies, you just get an error when you try to access it.^^:;
Lilo's uninstall is more like an undo than an uninstall.  Means that if you change it twice, you can't go back to the first.
- lol - lilo is scarey - it can turn your display into a stream of flowing zeros if the disk isn't handled correctly.
